column7: Robert Myslajek stops. Between two paw prints on a mountain path
column8: the scientist finds what he is looking for. “Droppings!” he says happily. It is so rare to see a wolf that seeing droppings makes it a good day. But it is getting easier to see a wolf. There are now about 1
column9: 500 wolves in Poland. The number has doubled in 15 years. The wolf
column11: the lynx and the wolverine are Europe's last large predator carnivores. Scientists from Britain
column12: Germany and the Netherlands are coming here to find out how Poland has saved wolves who have a bad reputation even in fairy tales.

column7: The scientist says wolves can move up to 30 kilometers during a single hunt. “The pack that he is tracking is a strong group of eight or nine animals. This year
column9: two young wolves and two adults. We track them using special cameras in the forest and by following their prints in the mud and snow. In each family group
column10: only one pair of adults has cubs each year. All the wolves in the pack look after the young.” Myslajek
column12: doesn't understand wolves' bad reputation. “Why did we have to have the fairy tale Little Red Riding Hood
column13: with its big bad wolf?” He is fascinated by these animals
column15: 000 years ago when other types of dog decided on a much more comfortable life as pets.

column7: Galina Zaglumyonova was woken in her flat in central Chelyabinsk by a very big explosion that broke the balcony windows and broken pots containing her houseplants. When she jumped out of bed she could see a huge vapor trail in the morning sky and hear car alarms from the street below. “I didn't understand what was going on
column8: ” said Zaglumyonova. “There was a big explosion and then lots of little explosions. My first thought was that it was a plane crash.” In fact
column9: it was a ten-ton meteorite that fell to Earth in lots of pieces. Almost 1
column10: 200 people were injured. More than 40 people were taken to hospital – most of them were hurt by flying glass. There were no deaths.

column7: Scientists must find new names for the elements but
column9: they must suggest two-letter symbols for the elements. When IUPAC has received the researchers' suggestions
column10: they will tell the public so that people can comment on the names. That allows scientists and others to find any problems with the names. In 1996
column11: someone suggested the symbol Cp for copernicium
column13: but it was changed to Cn
column14: when scientists complained that Cp was already the symbol for another substance.

column7: The survival of Poland's wolves has been helped by the country's belated infrastructure development. In 1989
column9: Poland had only one motorway. Major road projects – requiring wildlife impact studies – began after Poland joined the European Union in 2004. The country now has one of the highest densities in the world of overhead crossings and underpasses for wild animals. Attitudes have also changed. “For many years
column11: there were fewer than 100 wolves in Poland. Beginning in the 1950s
column12: hunting wolves had been encouraged by the authorities. They paid a reward for killing a wolf worth a month's salary. It was carnage.” Myslajek says the improvement in Polish wolves' survival chances has been considerable but remains fragile. Packs are mobile across borders and hunting still goes on in neighboring Russia

column7: The sales tax break was created to help people on islands survive when lots of people were emigrating. Islands that are popular with tourists
column9: fear that losing the tax break will make things very hard for them. But
column11: it is a much bigger problem. “If we have to pay a tax of 23%
column12: we will all die on the island
column13: ” says Kakali. Food and fuel are already more expensive than on mainland Greece. Even in summer
column14: the island has only three shops
column15: two restaurants and not one official hotel. “This is an expensive island. Everything
column17: has been bought and sold three or four times by middlemen before it gets to us and so is very expensive

column8: Leading water scientists have issued one of the sternest warnings yet about global food supplies
column9: saying that the world's population may have to switch almost completely to a vegetarian diet by 2050 to avoid catastrophic shortages. Humans derive about 20% of their protein from animal-based products now
column10: but this may need to drop to just 5% to feed the extra two billion people expected to be alive by 2050
column11: according to research by some of the world's leading water scientists. “There will not be enough water available on current croplands to produce food for the expected nine-billion population in 2050 if we follow current trends and changes towards diets common in western nations
column12: ” the report by Malik Falkenmark and colleagues at the Stockholm International Water Institute (SIWI) said.
